sub_topic: Solving homogeneous systems of linear equations
message_1:
Solve the following homogeneous system of linear equations using matrix operations:

$x + 3y + 2z = 0$

$5x - 2y + 4z = 0$

$2x + y - 3z = 0$
message_2:
To solve the given homogeneous system of linear equations using matrix operations, we first write the system in matrix form:

$A\vec{x} = \vec{0}$, where $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 5 & -2 & 4 \\ 2 & 1 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$, $\vec{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}$, and $\vec{0} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$.

Now, we will perform Gaussian elimination to find the reduced row echelon form (RREF) of matrix $A$:

1. Swap row 1 and row 2 to have the largest absolute value in the first column at the top:
$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 4 \\ 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & -3 \end{bmatrix}$

2. Replace row 2 with (-1/5)row 1 + row 2, and row 3 with (-2/5)row 1 + row 3:
$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 3.4 & 0.4 \\ 0 & 1.4 & -4.6 \end{bmatrix}$

3. Divide row 2 by 3.4:
$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 2/17 \\ 0 & 1.4 & -4.6 \end{bmatrix}$

4. Replace row 3 with (-1.4)row 2 + row 3:
$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 2/17 \\ 0 & 0 & -76/17 \end{bmatrix}$

5. Divide row 3 by (-76/17):
$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 4 \\ 0 & 1 & 2/17 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

6. Replace row 1 with (-4)row 3 + row 1, and row 2 with (-2/17)row 3 + row 2:
$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

7. Replace row 1 with (2/5)row 2 + row 1:
$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

Now we have the identity matrix, which means the system has a unique solution:

$x = 0$

$y = 0$

$z = 0$

So, the solution to the homogeneous system of linear equations is $(x, y, z) = (0, 0, 0)$.
